contentrichtext.text: {{Other people2|Herbert Bauer (disambiguation){{!}}Herbert Bauer}} {{eastern name order|Balázs Béla}} {{Expand Hungarian|Balázs Béla|date=May 2010}} [[File:TóthSándorBalázsBélaKJ.JPG|thumb|right|Béla Balázs (bronze portrait by Sándor Tóth)]] '''Béla Balázs''' ({{IPA-hu|ˈbeːlɒ ˈbɒlaːʒ|lang}}; 4 August 1884, [[Szeged]] – 17 May 1949, [[Budapest]]), born '''Herbert Bauer''', was a [[Hungary|Hungarian]]-[[Jew]]ish [[film criticism|film critic]], [[aesthetics|aesthete]], [[writer]] and [[poet]]. ==Career== Balázs was the son of German-born parents, adopting his ''nom de plume'' in newspaper articles written before his 1902 move to Budapest, where he studied Hungarian and German at the Eötvös Collegium. Balázs was a moving force in the [[Sonntagskreis]] or Sunday Circle, the intellectual discussion group which he founded in the autumn of 1915 together with Lajos Fülep, [[Arnold Hauser]], [[György Lukács]] and [[Karl Mannheim|Károly (Karl) Mannheim]]. Meetings were held at his flat on Sunday afternoons; already in December 1915 Balázs wrote in his diary of the success of the group.<ref name=gluck>Mary Gluck (1985) [http://books.google.it/books?id=TUdmFkDoIGUC&pg=PA15 ''Georg Lukács and His Generation, 1900-1918'']. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. pp. 14–16</ref> He is perhaps best remembered as the librettist of ''[[Bluebeard's Castle]]'' which he originally wrote for his roommate [[Zoltán Kodály]], who in turn introduced him to the eventual composer of the opera, [[Béla Bartók]]. This collaboration continued with the scenario for the ballet ''[[The Wooden Prince]]''. The collapse of the short-lived [[Hungarian Soviet Republic]] under [[Béla Kun]] in 1919 began a long period of exile in Vienna and Germany and, from 1933 until 1945, the Soviet Union. [[Georg Lukács|György Lukács]], a close friend during their youth, became a bitter enemy during the ordeal of the [[Great Purge|Stalinist purges]]. In Vienna he became a prolific writer of film reviews. His first book on film, ''Der Sichtbare Mensch'' (''The Visible Man'') (1924), helped found the [[Germany|German]] "film as a language" theory, which also exerted an influence on [[Sergei Eisenstein]] and [[Vsevolod Pudovkin]]. A popular consultant, he wrote the screenplay for [[G. W. Pabst]]'s film of ''[[The Threepenny Opera (1931 film)|Die Dreigroschenoper]]'' (1931), which became the object of a scandal and lawsuit by [[Bertolt Brecht|Brecht]] (who admitted to not reading the script) during production. Later, he co-wrote (with [[Carl Mayer]]) and helped [[Leni Riefenstahl]] direct the film ''[[Das Blaue Licht]]'' ([[1932 in film|1932]]). Riefenstahl later removed his and Mayer's name from the credits because they were Jewish.<ref>[http://www.uni-konstanz.de/FuF/Philo/LitWiss/MedienWiss/Forsch/Telaviv/Riefenstahl-englisch.html Hanno Loewy: "Balazs' and Leni Riefenstahl's The blue Light. A martyr's story"]</ref> One of his best known films is ''[[Somewhere in Europe]]'' (''It Happened in Europe'', 1947), directed by [[Géza von Radványi]]). His last years were marked by petty vexations at home and ever increasing recognition in the German speaking world. In 1949, he received the most distinguished prize in [[Hungary]], the [[Kossuth Prize]]. Also in 1949, he finished ''Theory of the Film'' published posthumously in English (London: Denis Dobson, 1952). In 1958, the Béla Balázs Prize was founded and named for him as an award to recognize achievements in [[cinematography]]. ==Selected filmography== * ''[[Madame Wants No Children]]'' (1926) * ''[[Doña Juana (film)|Doña Juana]]'' (1927) ==See also== {{portal|Poetry}} * [[:Category:Ballets by Béla Balázs|Ballets by Béla Balázs]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.kirjasto.sci.fi/balazs.htm Biography and list of writings] * {{IMDb name | id = 0051354 | name = Béla Balázs }} * {{gutenberg author | id=Béla_Balázs | name=Béla Balázs}} * {{OL author|OL4633586A}} * [http://www.uni-konstanz.de/FuF/Philo/LitWiss/MedienWiss/Forsch/Telaviv/Riefenstahl-englisch.html Article on the relationship between Riefenstahl and Balazs] * [http://jewish.hu/view.php?clabel=balazs_bela Béla Balázs on Jewish.hu's list of famous Hungarian Jews] {{Authority control|VIAF=9842518}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Balazs, Bela | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 4 August 1884 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 17 May 1949 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Balazs, Bela}} [[Category:Hungarian writers]] [[Category:Hungarian poets]] [[Category:Ballet librettists]] [[Category:Film theorists]] [[Category:Hungarian critics]] [[Category:Film critics]] [[Category:Philosophers of art]] [[Category:Jewish writers]] [[Category:Hungarian Jews]] [[Category:People from Szeged]] [[Category:1884 births]] [[Category:1949 deaths]] [[Category:Burials at Kerepesi Cemetery]]
